Geologist Ro Kinzler.
It turns out that we are most likely in an "ice age" now. So, in fact, the last ice age hasn't ended yet!



Scientists call this ice age the Pleistocene Ice Age. It has been going on since about 2.5 million years ago (and some think that it's actually part of an even longer ice age that started as many as 40 million years ago).
The curious thing about ice ages is that the temperature of Earth's atmosphere doesn't stay cold the entire time. Instead, the climate flip-flops between what scientists call "glacial periods" and "interglacial periods."



Glacial periods last tens of thousands of years. Temperatures are much colder, and ice covers more of the planet.



On the other hand, interglacial periods last only a few thousand years and the climate conditions are similar to those on Earth today.
We are in an interglacial period right now. It began at the end of the last glacial period, about 10,000 years ago.





Scientists are still working to understand what causes ice ages. One important factor is the amount of light Earth receives from the Sun. The amount of sunlight that reaches Earth can vary quite a lot, mainly due to three factors:
how much Earth is tilted relative to the Sun whether Earth wobbles a lot or a little as it spins on its axis
(kind of like how a toy top can wobble a lot or a little as it spins) the shape of Earth's orbit as it goes around the Sun (whether it is shaped more like a circle or more like an ellipse or oval)

Over thousands of years, the amount of sunshine reaching Earth changes by quite a lot, particularly in the northern latitudes, the area near and around the North Pole. When less sunlight reaches the northern latitudes, temperatures drop and more water freezes into ice, starting an ice age. When more sunlight reaches the northern latitudes, temperatures rise, ice sheets melt, and the ice age ends. But there are many other factors. So if you became a climate scientist one day, you could make your own discoveries!



To find out more about Earth's climate in the past, scientists study ice cores. These samples tell us that during the current ice age, climate on Earth has flip-flopped between glacial and interglacial periods at least 17 times!
So it is very likely that Earth will turn cold again, possibly within the next several thousand years. But, we have to keep in mind that human activities today are impacting climate on a global scale. So when we predict future climate changes, including the next glacial period, we need to consider the changes that humans are causing.



Keep on asking questions! There's still much we don't know about the past and future of our planet.

"Climate change" is not a re-branding of "global warming": It refers to the broader range of phenomena cause by man-made global warming, including changing seasons, intensifying droughts and wildfires, more extreme precipitation when the skies do open up, changing precipitation due to more days being above freezing, other changes in precipitation due to disruption of the jet stream and water cycle due to man-made global warming, hurricanes intensifying more rapidly, traveling slower, and degrading more slowly over land, etc.

Personally, I prefer "man-made global warming and climate disruption."

Sea level rise isn't even across the planet. It's falling close to melting ice sheets, due to reduced ice mass reducing gravitational pull towards the sheets. And changes in wind patterns, ocean salinity and ocean currents - e g. the gulf stream is slowing down causing rapid SL rise along US east coast. If the gulf stream (amoc) stops altogether then sea level will rise about 1m along the US east coast and that's on top of any general global increase.

You really have NO IDEA about the relevant science do you ?
The poles are both within NORMAL variability , both the Antarctic AND Greenland are cooling
overall the Antarctic for 35 years now .
There has been NO overall global increase for some years now, the land surface temp in the U.S has not warmed overall since 2005, and as that system was set up in 2005, we have to look at other data before that, the onset of the pause was in 1998.
Tokyo has NOT warmed overall for decades and a Japanese island had NOT warmed overall for 71 years !
Our fossil fuels are likely adding some warming to the natural warming we are in but as Co2 has NEVER been a major forcing on global temperature that is not likely to be much.
Remember the MORE atmospheric Co2 the LESS additional warming you get, its effect is logarithmic NOT linear, so you can double Co2 without much temperature increase, its greatest warming effect is at 20 ppm, with every doubling after that the additional warming is smaller and smaller.
The paleoclimate data is clear its warming temperatures that drive up atmospheric Co2 levels with a lag of 800-1000 years (how long ago was the medieval Warm Period ?), higher co2 levels NEVER prevent subsequent cooling !, in fact Co2 continues to rise for some time after temperatures fall overall.
You can see that with the onset of the short term cooling phase in 1940 that ran for 37 years till 1977, WW2 pushed up Co2 emissions but temperature fell as it does, before warming again after 1977.
That cooling phase followed the previous warming phase which peaked in the late 1930's
(and still holds the records for the longest period of hot weather and the highest number of broken high temperature records in the U.S), the long term temperature record is one long series of warmings and coolings over a variety of time cycles running simultaneously.
Remember the Medieval warm period was at least as warm as now and probably warmer, the Roman warm period as warmer still, the Minoan warming was warmer again and the Holocene Thermal Optimum was as hot as its been in the current interglacial, (though the previous two interglacials were both significantly warmer than ours has been).
Overall the peak warmings have been getting shorter and cooler over the last 11000 years as we move back into the next glacial over the next few thousand years.

@@hahnilso3187 "we are entering an interstadal glacial period. Like all others it will last at least 20,000 years." You are talking about how the cycles worked before we increased global CO2 levels--which changes everything. We are driving global temps and all the feedback loops away from an ice age. Human activity is now the main force shaping the future of life on Earth. /

"Carbon has exclusively followed warming and cooling trends on the planet by 300 years and it has been like this for millions of years." That's oversimplifying Earth's history AND how temps, CO2, and water vapor interact. First, at some points in earth's history, there were massive releases of CO2 which drove warming. Second, the relationship is reciprocal and bi-directional: Whichever you increase first will increase the other. If you increases temps first (as orbital cycles have done), that inevitably triggers more CO2, which triggers more water vapor, which triggers still more CO2 release, more warming, more water vapor, and so on. Thus, a great deal of the eventual warming in past warming periods was actually due to the release of CO2, even if some initial warming was triggered first.

Third, we know this time around, our release of massive amounts of CO2 is what caused the warming. Natural drivers account for a whopping net ZERO warming from 1880-2020: ALL of it is accounted for by our release of greenhouse gases, deforestation and tilling (which alter the carbon cycle) and the amplification effects of more water vapor caused by the evaporation caused by the original warming caused by more CO2.

Sorry, we know we caused it this time around.

Take care.

The diversity of life on earth now is perhaps as great as it has ever been AND we evolved in cooler conditions with lower CO2 levels. We're not dinosaurs, so it doesn't matter what conditions were even then, because all life on Earth has been adapted to cooler temps and lower CO2 levels for a couple million years, and if you rapidly change the Earth's conditions, things go extinct. The last time the Earth warmed this rapidly and oceans acidified this rapidly, 95% of marine life went extinct as did 70% of life on land, including everything over 90 pounds. Species can adapt if you change conditions very slowly over thousands or millions of years, but if you rapidly disrupt their habitats, they go extinct: Due to man-made global warming, ecosystem destruction, direct killing of species and chemical and plastic pollution, we are already racing down the on-ramp to the sixth mass extinction of life on earth.

We can change course and save most of the millions of species on Earth, but it requires decarbonizing our economy and shrinking consumption in wealthy countries to fit within the limits of what the Earth can provide and withstand.

I know what you are angling at. But before I say I must add that I am aware that in the past life has endured much higher levels of CO2 equivalent challenges. However, there has been a gradual descent of CO2 concentrations and corresponding global mean temperatures beginning 50 million years ago at the Cenozoic thermal maximum when terrestrial life endured much higher temperatures by habitating the higher latitudes. Much of the oceans may have still have not yet recovered from the devastating effects of the PETM.

There were two short-lived interruptions, one of which was likely a result of flood volcanism. It provided a mile thick lava cap on the geology of Eastern Washington, parts of Idaho and parts of Northern Oregon associated with the Columbia River basin. Geologically this is considered to be a minor large igneous province or deep mantle plume volcanism. There was quite a bit of thawing at both poles.

However, ultimately 2.6 million years ago we entered into the ice age described as the Quaternary which we are currently disrupting and departing from. In contrast to Earth's geologic history during which there have been much warmer periods, even as we have cycled between glaciations and interglacials, we have enjoyed a very mild climate that has fostered abundant and diverse ecosystems both on land and in water.

With the very abrupt changes that are now occurring this abundance is working against us. On land, more and more it's biomass is entering the domain of Fire. In water, beyond the effects of overfishing, acidification, eutrophication with subsequent hypoxia, anoxia, and euxenia, along with warming are ravaging ecosystem complexity as well as driving some of the mobile towards the poles.

Also, under rather thin subsea permafrost perched on the shallow Arctic Ocean's shelves there are large catches of methane contained in temperature stabilized hydrates, aka clathrates, that have likely been accumulating at least during the last 800,000 years since we had transitioned into 100,000 year glaciation cycles.

Increasing insolation absorbing open Arctic Ocean water is a very large threat in consideration of the above described situation and large releases of methane there will be much more impactful than normal. Hydroxyl radicals that low temperature oxidize methane into CO2 and H2O form from the photolysis of water vapor in the upper troposphere. There is much less water vapor in the colder Arctic atmosphere. With rapid releases a methane in the Arctic higher concentrations will subsequently there localize to the extent that it's CO2 equivalent forcing value will be 150 to 200 times that of CO2 rather than the normal quoted value of 86 times over two decades. Thus feeding back on itself visions of the fabled clathrate gun nightmare begin to appear.

We could tolerate much warmer temperatures by shifting towards the poles. However, currently the dynamic is going to be very challenging for all of life currently residing on Earth.

This is an important message. But I think it's important to note that it doesn't stop getting worse at 3 degrees. If we do fail to prevent a rise of 3 degrees, we may still have a chance to prevent a rise of 4 degrees. And if we can't prevent a rise of 4 degrees, perhaps we can prevent a rise of 5 degrees. It keeps getting worse, ad infinitum, until we either solve this, or we start reaching levels where human extinction becomes a real possibility (my guess is that's around the 10 degree mark, based on what I've learned about the Permian extinction). The flip side of that is that no matter how bad it gets, it's always possible to prevent it from getting even worse, so don't give up if we fail to meet one goal (in fact IIRC stopping a 3 degree rise is already our second goalpost, since I remember a few years ago we were talking about trying to prevent a rise of 2 degrees).

"It keeps getting worse, ad infinitum, until we either solve this, or we start reaching levels where human extinction becomes a real possibility (my guess is that's around the 10 degree mark, based on what I've learned about the Permian extinction)." Disappointing. The two big complaints are due to their focus on the direct impacts from the environment over the next eighty years.

First, they miss the feedback loops that the gradually escalating interim crises will create. As rich countries are called upon for aid by their citizens, they'll be less likely to help poorer countries (witness the lack of COVID vaccines going to the poorest countries), or even cooperate with other wealthy countries (beyond lip service ‚Äî already evident at climate summits). The economic disruption will accelerate as the climate crisis becomes more and more evident, reducing the likelihood that anything ever gets done.

Second, by pointing to the 3¬∞C increase at the end of the century, they make it easy for people to treat this like a horror story that will maybe happen to strangers. ‚ÄúThat's a long time from now, surely someone will fix the problem well before then.‚Äù They should be pointing to the unprecedented flooding in Germany, the unprecedented heat wave in Australia, the melting of permafrost in Alaska and Siberia, the fires in the U.S. west ‚Äî all happening now, and all harbingers of worse to come. People need to be scared about their own futures, not that of their grandchildren's.

We are in a part of the Galaxy visited every 12,000 years, when we experience a major ice age.
At the opposite side of the Galaxy where we were 6,000 years ago we experienced a mini ice age.
Prior to each ice age our planetary system warms up, melting polar & mountain ice, causing the oceans to become less saline.
We also experience increases in Volcanic activity, which eventually results in the sun being blocked sufficiently to cause rapid cooling, thus an ice age.
The ice ages affect the northern hemisphere far more than the the southern.
In the case of major ice ages, the only region where life can survive for many generations is the equatorial zone, which is much colder but not the extreme conditions which make current Antarctic temperatures seem like a heatwave.

CO2 is a trace gas in the atmosphere only 0.04 percent, but the IPCC say that CO2 is a dangerous GHG because it absorbs and emits strongly at 15 microns. According to Wien's displacement law 15 microns has a corresponding temperature of -80‚Å∞ C. The troposphere, that's the part of the atmosphere we live in, is defined by molecules with a temperature of -60‚Å∞ C and above. Emissions of IR from CO2 @ 15 microns cannot heat any molecules in the troposphere. That would violate the laws of physics.

Why only 3 degrees higher? Why not 5 - 8 degrees. The later was the reality of the 'Paleocene-Eocene' Thermal Maximum' period that began around 56 million years ago.  Like the period before it there was no icecaps but with even higher temperatures and CO2 levels. Did the world shrivel up under the blistering heat? No, the fossil record shows it was covered in tropical rain forest and supported the development of early mammals including our primate ancestors. So instead of images of parched desserts, imagine sitting on the treetops looking out over a luxuriant green canopy or bathing in the warm waters of the arctic circle. If there ever was a 'Garden of Eden' that led to the eventual establishment of man this was it.  If you are still not convinced you only have to go back to the warmer periods in the Roman and Medieval times. The later witnessed Southern England with a climate akin to the Loire valley today and Greenland being more habitable than present (encouraging a brief Viking settlement). Let us not also forget the remains of vast forests that lie under Northern Tundra revealing a time of warmer weather that made more of the world more habitable.

See James Hanson's solutions on his 'You Tube' talks.  One, have a carbon fee to be directly paid back to the general public.  Two, get the US and China to cooperate on this and on developing technologies to overcome these dangers so drawing in others.  I'd hope IF that could nbe set up the EU will join.  That will mean perhaps all the major economoes joining that must draw in the rest.  This is an excellent video but I suggest in future any such video includes James Hanson.   Before we lose him.

@@necrym941 "Sorry all climate is cyclic regardless of wether we are here for the complete cycle or not. Planetary climate is dictated to by one thing alone - the sun." False. MANY things shape the climate and burning 650 million years of the sun's stored energy means the lower atmosphere holds in for longer more and more of the energy that the sun bombards us with every day. It's like adding another blanket to your bed--the blanket doesn't create any energy but holds in more energy for longer. Part of that is directly held in by the CO2, but that warming causes evaporation and that added water vapor in the sky is responsible for about 50% or more of the total global warming. But without the added CO2, which doesn't precipitate out of the atmosphere, the added water vapor would just precipitate out of the atmosphere.

Global population growth is only a small part of the problem. We could hover at around the same global population and we would still be decimated by climate change. The real problem is how we produce commodities and how we generate electricity. These 2 things - intense industry and coal fired power plants - drive the problem of climate change. For example, meat production is responsible for 15% of global man-made climate change. We could entirely eliminate this and rely on meat substitutes or make a push for vegetarianism. No de-population needed. 25% of global man made emissions are from electricity and heat production, so switch to renewables and create more efficient heating mechanisms. No de-population needed and we're almost halfway there! The economic incentive of oil, gas, meat production, and all fossil fuels needs to be removed if we want to survive as a species - de-population or not.

As energy consumption per head will double until the end of the century, and 3 bn people still live in poverty and will have to use the cheap carbon energy storages we can expect a 4-6 Kelvin increase if the models are correct.
Pole temperatures will increase the most as the arctic albedo collapses once the very thin 3-4 m thick ice shield is melted away permanently. Up to plus 6-8 Kelvin rise will result. However it will take centuries for Greenland ice to melt away.
1200ppm CO2 will be reached, which will see a dramatic increase in plant growth and vegetation density. Fauna will follow flora. Temperatures on the equator will be only about 2 Kelvin higher, While desert belts will be moved to slightly higher latitudes.
No one really believes that energy consumption will stall or even decrease. Economists know this would lead to large scale wars. So if the models are correct this scenario has a bigger than 90% chance to play out. Adaptation is the way that all life goes when climate changes happen. Adaptation is about 90% more effective than mitigation, while resistance leads to extinction , and is the least (or most) effective depending on the perspective. This is where businesses show their agility. They quickly adapt and everything becomes green and clean, and sustainable, Adaptation is the secret of evolution and the most energy efficient response to climate change. As humans change the planet, the consequence is that they have to adapt.And as humans are very adaptive, most futurists predict a bright, even if slightly warmer future for our civilization. One thing is clear, panic never improved the odds of survival. So we must at least keep our heads cool and adapt. The gap of poor and rich was never a climate issue. It was and will always be a competition issue, a pure free market concept that nature invented to drive evolution. Over sufficiently long periods of time there are no winners and losers. In a couple of hundred years Europe could be a basket case, while Africa is Utopia. Of course, this is not to justify complacency in the face of stark inequalities, but it is a view beyond human life spans on par with climate changes which always were a main driver of civilizatory evolution. So it all comes down to how much and how quickly we have to adapt. A generational cycle is natural, a higher adaptation rate will cause extra stress. However, with the current measures taken, there will be no catastrophic stress. That would occur with a planet killer asteroid appearing 5 years out from Earth, or the collapse of Earth‚Äòs magnet field. With cool heads and our given intelligence we will learn and adapt and of course survive. We should not spread fear and depression but confidence and optimism, in particular those who have sufficient knowledge on this matter.

The Climate Waits for No One
Thirty years ago, a friend of mine got into the green energy business and tried to pull me into it. I asked him what for, it isn‚Äôt serious. He said, ‚ÄúYou have no idea how much money is being poured into it. Everyone wants in on it, politicians, financiers, businesspeople, the lot.‚Äù He was right, of course. Yet, no one wants to promote green energy in order to save the planet, but only to swell up their pockets even more. The declarations, therefore, remain in the assembly hall where they are stated, necessary actions are ignored, and the climate waits for no one: It will keep deteriorating.
This week in Glasgow, Scotland, the 26th UN Climate Change Conference is taking place. Officially, it aims to ‚Äúbring parties together to accelerate action towards the goals of the Paris Agreement and the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change.‚Äù In reality, the countries plan to do the exact opposite. This year‚Äôs UN Production Gap Report, which tracks the discrepancy between governments‚Äô planned fossil fuel production and actual global production levels, states the following: ‚ÄúDespite increased climate ambitions and net-zero commitments, governments still plan to produce more than double the amount of fossil fuels in 2030 than what would be consistent with limiting global warming to 1.5¬∞C [2.7¬∞F].‚Äù
Energy sources and technologies do change, but not according to what is best for the planet. It changes according to the interests of politicians and money moguls, and it never benefits the planet or the majority of its inhabitants, namely all of us.
Since the climate waits for no one, eventually, it will catch up with us. Earth is a closed system, and in a closed system, there are consequences to exploitation: it hurts the abuser as well as the abused.
I don‚Äôt know when or at what cost, but eventually, we will all have to realize that we cannot take beyond what we need. We cannot keep exploiting Earth selfishly and thoughtlessly because it will turn against us.
Earth is like a submarine: there is only so much oxygen on board. If some crew members take more than their quota, the rest will not have enough, they will die, and the submarine will sink along with those who exceeded their quota.
We need constant reminders that we are one system, and we are all dependent on each other. We need to genuinely grasp that selfishness hurts us just as being exploitative hurts others. If we constantly remind ourselves that we are interdependent, we will behave with more consideration, and we will avoid the punitive impact of climate change.
The other option is to keep working as the UN‚Äôs Production Gap Report states that we are planning to work, and suffer nature‚Äôs unforgiving response. I hope we wise up in time because everyone will pay the price for this mistake.
We can do better

According to well understood physical parameters, the effectiveness of CO2 as a greenhouse gas diminishes logarithmically with increasing concentration and from the current level of ~390 ppmv, (parts per million by volume). Accordingly only ~5% of the effectiveness of CO2 as a greenhouse gas remains beyond the current level.This inconvenient fact is well understood in the climate science community. It can be accurately modeled using the Modtran program maintained and supported at the University of Chicago.The logarithmic diminution of the effect of CO2 is probably the reason why there was no runaway greenhouse warming from CO2 in earlier eons when CO2 levels were known to be at levels of several thousands ppmv.Remarkably, IPCC Published reports , (TAR3), do actually acknowledge that the effective temperature increase caused by growing concentrations of CO2 in the atmosphere radically diminishes with increasing concentrations. This information is in their report. It is well disguised for any lay reader, (Chapter 6. Radiative Forcing of Climate Change: section 6.3.4 Total Well-Mixed Greenhouse Gas Forcing Estimate).Although the IPCC tacitly acknowledges that this crucial diminution effect with increasing concentrations effect exists, it certainly does not go out of its way to emphasise it. Like the Medieval Warm Period, that they attempted to eliminate with the Hockey Stick graph in 2001, the panel knows that wide public knowledge of the diminution effect with increasing CO2 concentration would be utterly detrimental to their primary message.From the present concentration of atmospheric CO2 at approaching 400 ppmv, only ~5% of the effectiveness of CO2 as a Greenhouse Gas remains. This can only give rise to a maximum of a further of ~+0.21¬∞C. Thereafter beyond 1000+ ppmv the effect of increasing levels of CO2 can only ever be absolutely minimal even if CO2 concentrations were to increase indefinitely.

Correct, so far as it goes. However, remember that we have not yet actually reached equilibrium for the current concentration of greenhouse gasses. We still have about 1 degree C of unrealized warming already in motion.
So really, current and future CO2 output, as you say, have minimal effect - but our past output will keep catching up to us for a decade or two yet.

@@Bookhermit What you are say is interesting. Could you please give me a little more detail on the 1 degree C of unrealised warming already in motion. I only ask because we have not reached 400ppm overnight. Yes, we have seen a record increase in the atmospheric level of CO2, and this is certainly, mostly, as a result of human activity, but back in 1960 we were already at 320ppm; so, even then, CO2 had already exhausted most of its greenhouse effect. There are simply too many of us primates on this planet. By our numbers it's pretty clear that we are an example of an architype Mother Nature dearly loves. Herds. From the age of the dinosaurs to todays fish in the seas, birds in the air and past buffalo, elephants and the like it appears she favors large masses, agglomerations, of biological entities.

So humanity is her latest experiment in the architype. This time she's created an intelligent herd.

But as bright as we are, as intelligent as we appear to be, in a group context we don't seem especially wise. In a group setting we are the exact opposite of those past herds who accepted and lived within the constraints of their environment.

In fact we seem prone to irrational acts of folly. Stupidity, self-interest, avarice and greed, is our norm in large groups. A not especially evolutionarily attractive trait in a species. So the experiment, overall, seems now to be in jeopardy.

It comes to this. We either learn to control ourselves and our numbers, acknowledging that as big as this planet is it is, in fact, a Terrarium. A closed loop dynamic system with limits. We either understand this and begin to comport ourselves along those informed lines, or Mother Nature will do it for us.

Given her tendency she will not care how much we scream about what she does. Our sensibilities aren't hers. She will reduce our numbers for us.

But for now we still have the choice. We have the option for self-control. We can reign ourselves in. Or not.

So choose wisely my primate friends. Choose wisely. The future awaits what we do today.

Ireland was traditionally a forest of deciduous hardwoods. Oak, Ash and sycamore and elm as such like trees. Now most of our forestry is Sitka spruce, fast growing and profitable in 20 years as opposed to 40-50 years for hardwoods. A multigenerational finance system is needed at government level to pay forestry workers a wage now for hardwoods which might take 50 years to give a return. This cannot be done at family level like other farm enterprises such as animal or crop production.
Our forestry companies using spruce and such softwoods cause environmental damage because when the forests are cleared this results in rapid water release in heavy rain storms, deciduous hold onto water runoff for longer and have better support for native wildlife and are better for the environment.
The solution to this problem will take a long time due to divisive interests and short-term financial thinking among a lot of the stakeholders concerned.

The West without Water: What Can Past Droughts Tell Us About Tomorrow?

As bad and worrisome as these more recent historical droughts in California and the West were, they pale in comparison to events uncovered in the geological record.

A glance into the history of the Southwest reminds us that the climate and rainfall patterns have varied tremendously over time, with stretches of drought many decades longer than the one we are experiencing now. Long dry stretches during the Medieval centuries (especially between 900 and 1350 CE) had dramatic effects on the native peoples of the Southwest (the ancestral Pueblo, Hohokam, and Sinagua), including civilizational collapse, violence, malnutrition, and forced social dislocation. These earlier Americans are a warning to us.

The past 150 years, which we have used as our baseline for assumptions about rainfall patterns, water availability for agriculture, water laws, and infrastructure planning, may in fact be an unusually wet period.

Powell published Report On The Lands Of The Arid Regions of the United States [1879], a careful assessment of the region‚Äôs capacity to be developed. In it, Powell argued that very little of the West could sustain agriculture. In fact, his calculations suggested that even if all the water in western streams were harnessed, only a tiny fraction of the land could be irrigated.

When Powell presented his findings to Congress, politicians howled. Powell found himself denounced by pro-development forces, including railroads and agricultural interests. Prescient as Powell‚Äôs study has proved to be, it was almost entirely ignored at the time.

In the 20th century, the single driest year (rivaling the 2013-2014 water year) was the drought of 1976-1977, extending across the entire state of California and into the Northwest, the Midwest, and the Canadian Prairie region north of Montana.

Lots of scientist are talking about it, one of the more vocal ones are prof Tim Garrett & co with their "growth as a symptom" hypothesis. They treat civilization like a ‚Äúheat engine‚Äù that ‚Äúconsumes energy and does 'work' in the form of economic production, which then spurs it to consume more energy.‚Äù Their study came to two surprising conclusions. First, although improving efficiency through innovation is a hallmark of efforts to reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions, efficiency has the side effect of making it easier for civilization to grow and consume more. Second, that the current rates of world population growth may not be the cause of rising rates of energy consumption, but a symptom of past efficiency gains.

"Advocates of energy efficiency for climate change mitigation may seem to have a reasonable point," Garrett says, "but their argument only works if civilization maintains a fixed size, which it doesn't. Instead, an efficient civilization is able to grow faster. It can more effectively use available energy resources to make more of everything, including people. Expansion of civilization accelerates rather than declines, and so do its energy demands and CO2 emissions."

I live in Cincinnati, and just moved to the area a bit over 15 years ago and climate change here has actually been OK, and is forecast to be OK. We should get (and have gotten) milder springs, summers and falls, and more rainfall overall. But winters are just less predictable; on average much warmer, but also with more snow and rain in winter than we are use to, and less ice.

So basically our manic up-and-down temps that we typically have had in the spring and fall are going to continue to even out, and summer will be slightly cooler day-to-day with increased chances for the occasional hot spike, and winter will be less and less predictable but overall much warmer on average. And that is the weird thing with climate change... it is change. Places further north are likely to have slightly cooler summers, but much warmer winters. Some places will see 5-15*c warming in heat islands, while others will see little to no impact. To say that it will be all-bad for everyone is frankly not true, but to say that it will not cause a lot of trouble for a lot of people, and that a lot of adaption will need to be made is probably a point that can't be driven home hard enough.

Too much climate change commentary leaves out the problem of feedback loops and tipping points. Once we reach certain thresholds these can trigger even more changes which can become like an avalanche. I don't think humanity itself will be wiped out or made 'extinct' but what will become increasingly common is the breakdown of civilisation and more and more collapsed societies. I'm sure humanity will cling on for many more generations, but in what shape will we be? As our world deteriorates in every way, we will slowly lose any sense of hope and optimism for the future. What will children dream of in 2100? I still find it incomprehensible that many politicians and of course fossil fuel execs believe that this hellish vision for possibly the only intelligent life in the universe, is worth trading off for a few more years of profits before they are finally forced to admit that they are sitting on stranded assets. So basically our entire ecological system and millenia of human civilisation are worth a few more Louis Vuitton handbags and luxury cars. That's what we've come to folks.

i can tell you about the documentary showing climate refugees in Bangladesh, since, i am from that part of the world and problem with Bangladesh is overpopulation and not enough land...cyclones AKA hurricanes are a seasonal phenomenon there and are essential for the monsoon to happen...cyclones have been periodically happening since forever...so flooding and high rainfall is a common occurrence. what is happening is these people are migrating to the mangrove forests in Bangladesh delta and cutting and clearing the trees. the mangrove forests AKA the "Sundarbans", are the largest mangrove forest on earth and the entire region of Bangladesh has subtropical climate having 90% above humidity,  winter season lasts 1 month max....the region is the Indo-Gangetic delta also the largest delta on earth....the mangrove forests are the lifeblood of the region, now people are migrating there and cutting down the forest for agricultural land, fisheries etc....Now there is nothing to stop the full force of the seasonal hurricanes and it reaches inland....this is more to do with overpopulation and deforestation than carbon emissions of someone sitting in the US.....
